Description: CVS Caremark Corporation agreed to pay $5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it misrepresented the prices of certain Medicare Part D prescription drugs -- including drugs used to treat breast cancer symptoms and epilepsy -- at CVS and Walgreens pharmacies. The allegedly deceptive claims caused many seniors and disabled consumers to pay significantly more for their drugs than they expected and pushed them into the "donut hole,"  a term referring to the coverage gap where none of their drug costs are reimbursed  sooner than they anticipated or planned. The settlement barred deceptive claims related to Medicare Part D drug prices and required CVS Caremark to pay $5 million to reimburse affected Medicare Part D consumers for the price discrepancy.

Description: To resolve a case involving allegations of unfair health insurance reimbursement rates, Aetna agreed to pay $20 million to a qualified nonprofit organization that would establish a new, independent database to help determine fair out-of-network reimbursement rates for consumers throughout the United States.
Aetna agreed to pay $175,000 to settle a lawsuit resulting from a mailing sent by the company to customers in which their HIV status was revealed through a transparent window in the envelopes.

The New York Attorney announced agreements with six health maintenance organizations that would empower consumers to challenge denials of coverage. The HMOs also agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the state AG's office to cover the cost of the investigation. The announcement did not specify how that cost would be divided among the six plans. Here we assume it was split equally.

Pharmacy benefit manager Caremark agreed to pay $38.5 million for costs of litigation and programs to benefit patients to settle multistate litigation alleging that it tricked doctors into switching patients to different brand name medications in order to receive secret rebates from drug manufacturers. Caremark also agreed to pay up to an additional $2.5 million in reimbursements to patients who paid extra because they were switched from one cholesterol-controlling drug to another.

Caremark LLC, a pharmacy benefit management company, agreed to pay a total of $1.94 million to five states -- Arkansas, California, Delaware, Louisiana and Massachusetts -- to settle allegations that it knowingly failed to reimburse Medicaid for prescription drug costs paid on behalf of Medicaid beneficiaries who also were eligible for drug benefits under Caremark-administered private health plans. This was part of a larger $4.25 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/cvs-caremark-will-pay-425-million-allegedly-denying-medicaid-claims-reimbursement

CVS agreed to pay $200,000 as part of a settlement of allegations it violated federal and state disability rights laws by failing to keep aisles clear for disabled customers, also violating a 2001 agreement previously filed.
CVS,Walgreens and Wal-Mart agreed to settle allegations they misled consumers in the collection of a $1.30 pharmacy assessment.

The New York Attorney General announced a settlement with four pharmacy chains requiring them to accept returnable beverage bottles and cans. The pharmacies also agreed to pay a total of $66,000 to the state. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amount was divided evenly among them.

CVS Caremark agreed to pay $15.6 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that the company from 2000 to 2006 improperly switched patients from the tablet version of the prescription drug Ranitidine (generic Zantac) to a more expensive capsule version in order to increase Medicaid reimbursement. This was part of a larger $36.7 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-cvs-caremark-corp-0
CVS agreed to pay $350,000 in settlement of allegations of restraint of trade and monopolization concerning the purchase and closing of a competing pharmacy.
CVS agreed to pay $895,000 to settle allegations it had charged the state full price for partially filled prescriptions and prescriptions that were ordered but never delivered.

CVS agreed to pay $4 million to a group of state and the federal government to settle allegations that it and and Revco Drugstores, Inc., a pharmacy chain it acquired, dispensed partial prescriptions due to insufficient stock but billed government health insurance programs for the full quantities prescribed for beneficiaries. The settlement was also announced by the U.S. Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-cvs-corporation

CVS agreed to pay $1.1 million as part of the settlement of multistate allegations that it charged consumers the full amount for prescriptions that were not completely filled due to insufficient inventory and then retained the excess payment if the consumer did not return to pick the remainder.
CVS agreed to pay $250,000 as part of the settlement of multistate litigation aimed reducing the sale of tobacco products to minors.

Description: As a result of provider complaints, the Department learned that starting in or about June 2007, Aetna paid certain out-of-network claims at a rate based on 125% of Medicare (75% of Medicare in the case of lab fees and durable medical equipment).  Aetna sent certain providers a letter stating the payment represented Aetna's determination of a fair payment and that additional reimbursement would not be considered.  Aetna applied this claims practice for services such as emergency care, services provided by nonparticipating providers during an admission to a network hospital, and services rendered as the result of a referral or authorization by Aetna.  In such cases, Aetna knew that its payment obligations exceeded what it paid and represented in its letters.  Aetna stated that a total of 130 providers were issued such a letter, with the first issued on or about June 8, 2007.
